body.p:
The appearance of your second article on “Interments in
public cemeteries” interspersed with a few lines quoted from
my last communication to you has really surprised me.
What I expected, and I think reasonably expected, was
that you should either publish my letter as it was,
or reject it entirely. But to pick out a few sentences
and place them before the public overwhelmed by your
own comments is most unreasonable and unfair.

You complain of my article not having been written
“in a spirit of respectful deference to our ecclesiastic-
al authorities.” This I cannot admit as I have said
nothing disrespectful of the personal character of either
of the Rabbis. I treated the subject and discussed the argu-
ments exclusively. But if we are not permitted to deal
with the opinions and decisions of higher officials, examine
them, and test their validity as whether they rest upon the
valid foundation of our canons, but are to submit blindly
to the judgment of others who happen to be placed in higher
positions than ourselves, then the study and knowledge of
our laws becomes a useless thing for Israelites in ordinary
positions of life, and then indeed freedom of speech or
religious questions would cease altogether even within
our own circle, and our religion degenerate into a
kind of popish subjection.

As Editor and proprietor of the “Occident” you
have the undoubted right to insert or reject any

article sent in for publication; but I cannot concede
that you have a right to select portions of my communi-
cation; bring my name before the public with an ac-
cusation of disrespect towards functionaries who
have a claim to our esteem without giving me a
fair opportunity of being judged by the public.
Even the very sentences quoted from my article are some-
what altered in a manner that neither the subject-
matter represented in them nor their grammatical
construction reflect credit on me. You say
“you would not have noticed my piece at all,
although the subject is of general interest, were it
not that I might otherwise have resorted to the pub-
lications called jewish, and pretended to say that I
could not obtain a hearing in this city.” But can
you truly say that I obtained a hearing in this
city by the publication of your long article
with a few fragments of my piece in it? If you
will point out wherein I have shown disrespect
to the Rabbi's personally I may alter or remove
those phrases but justice demands that you should
publish my article in its entire, especially now
as you have held me before the public in an un-
favorable light. Should you decline however
to do so rest assured that it will appear in some
form or other and perhaps is a more pungent form
than that in which I have written and if Hebrew
must be the consequence the sin will not be at
my door but at the door of my opponents who

it seems will not cease their attacks and vitupera
tions upon me, but will always find the mote? in my
eye while the beam is yet in theirs. With nearly
every one of those pious orthodox men who censure
my acts I could find fault for transgressing
some Hebrew laid down in the Hebrew the code they
profess to follow and from which they dictate
to others. I could point out many a transgression
of Hebrew as well as Hebrew which our ministers are
guilty of themselves of which they sanction? in others
yet I forbear Hebrew.

The publication of my remarks on Doctors
Adler and Pipernos letters would be an act
of mere justice due to me and to the cause of
truth, and if this is denied me in the organ
which opened its pages to denounce my act
I must seek justice at the hands of those who
are less prejudiced and more independent and
liberal.
